holidays.name: Agonalia
holidays.description: A holiday celebrating January's namesake, Janus, the god of doorways. Doorways and thresholds were considered places of vulnerability, and possibility. On the this holiday, the Romans would sacrifice a lamb for protection of the king.

holidays.name: Carmentalia
holidays.description: A holiday in honor of Carmenta, the goddess of childbirth, this holiday from the 11th to the 15th was celebrated on the Capitoline Hill.

holidays.name: Parentalia
holidays.description: A nine day holiday from the 13th to the 21st, the Parentalia were days on which to commemorate the dead -- especially departed parents. The Romans would gather to drink and place flowers, milk and wine at the graves of loved ones to keep them from trying to rejoin the living. This holiday was linked with the Cara Cognatio (on the 22nd) -- a holiday for making peace with the living.

holidays.name: Caristia
holidays.description: Following Parentalia, which made peace with the dead, Caristia was a feast to reunite the living and repair their quarrels, held in the presence of the family ghosts, who had received their gifts.

holidays.name: Lupercalia
holidays.description: Now rebranded as Valentine's Day, Lupercalia was celebrated in honor of Lupercus or Faunus. Teams of youth would dress in goatskins and blood, eat magnificently, and then chase around the the base of a hill snapping onlookers with goat skin strips called 'februa', hence the month name! Getting hit by one of the strips was supposed to promote fertility in women.

holidays.name: Quirinalia
holidays.description: Originally a Sabine war god, Quirinus (or, 'Oak Spear')was adopted by the Romans and made into another name for Jupiter, King of the Gods. This holiday is in his honor, and in this incarnation, he is associated with myrtle.

holidays.name: Feralia
holidays.description: To honor the dead, on Feralia the Romans would offer wreaths, bread soaked in wine, grain, salt and violet petals. According to Ovid, an older woman would drink, surrounded by a circle of girls, and would perform a rite for Tacita, the mute goddess. The woman would place three bits of incense, with three of her fingers, beneath a threshold where a mouse is unknowingly buried. She then rolled seven black beans in her mouth and smeared the head of a fish with pitch, impaling it with a bronze needle, and roasting it in a fire. After that she formally declaimed the purpose of her actions, saying 'I have gagged spiteful tongues and muzzled unfriendly mouths'

holidays.name: Terminalia
holidays.description: In honor of Terminus, the god of boundaries, this was a holiday which possibly originated in the countryside, where neighbors would meet at the boundaries of their land and give small sacrifices.

holidays.name: Regifugium
holidays.description: The flight of the king -- late Romans thought this had to do with the explusion of the last king of Rome.

holidays.name: Kalends
holidays.description: The day on which to re-kindle the perpetual fire which represented the life of Rome! Fresh laurels would be hung on buildings, and priests would dance sacred shield dances for the god Mars for nineteen days, dining at a different house each night

holidays.name: Equirria
holidays.description: Intended to purify the army and raise public morale, Equirria featured two-horse chariot races, and a scapegoat which was driven out of Rome.

holidays.name: Liberalia
holidays.description: A celebration of freedom from evil, burdens, care and folly -- and a continuation of the celebrations of Mars for the month! Boy woulds also be declared men on this day.

holidays.name: Quinquatrus
holidays.description: A celebration for Mars and Minerva -- since Minerva was the goddess of healing, this was widely celebrated by students, teachers, doctors and artisans.

holidays.name: Tubilustrium
holidays.description: A day for cleaning the war trumpets. A female lamb was sacrified in the Hall of Shoemakers, and the twelve leaping priests of Mars would dance in the streets.

holidays.name: Ludi Megalenses
holidays.description: Games were held from the 4th to the 10th. Originally held at the end of March, this holiday was in honor of the Great Mother, whose statue was washed on this day. Cybele, the Great Mother, was a goddess represented by a large stone brought to Rome in 204 BC by instruction of the Oracle of Delphi from Asia Minor.

holidays.name: Ludi Ceriales
holidays.description: From the 12th to the 19th, the Romans would hold games celebrating the crops -- during this holiday, they would release foxes with torches tied to their tails.

holidays.name: Parilia
holidays.description: Originally a countryside holiday for the ritual purification of sheep, Parilia later became a celebration of the founding of Rome with bonfires, feasting, and hunting hares in the Circus.

holidays.name: Vinalia
holidays.description: There were two Vinalia, holidays dedicated to Venus and Jupiter, and intended to protect the wine harvest. This is the first one, or the 'city' Vinalia. Participants would sample the last year's wine harvest and make an offering of wine to Jupiter, asking for good weather for the next wine harvest. The priest of Jupiter would bless the wine, and pour it outside of the temple of Venus. Women would make offerings of myrtle, mint and rushes concealed in roses, and ask the goddess for beauty, popularity, charm and wit.

holidays.name: Robigalia
holidays.description: A day in honor of Robigalia, a household god of agricultural disease, this festival was observed at a milestone outside of Rome. An unweaned puppy would be sacrificed to protect the fields.

holidays.name: Ludi Floriales
holidays.description: A celebration in honor of the goddess of flowers from April 28 to May 3rd. Tables would be piled high with flowers, participants would wear garlands, and there was a traditional burlesque dance.

holidays.name: Lemuria
holidays.description: Celebrated on the 9th, the 11th, and the 13th, Lemuria marked the days on which the dead could walk amongst the living. Participants would walk barefoot and cast black beans over their shoulders at midnight to satisfy the dead, while other household members would clash pots and pans to scare away the dead.

holidays.name: Agonalia
holidays.description: So named for the sacrifice of a ram, this was an ancient holiday to a very ancient, pre-Roman god, Vediovis. Probably a festival for protection.

holidays.name: Tubilustrium
holidays.description: A day for cleaning the war trumpets. A female lamb was sacrified in the Hall of Shoemakers, and the twelve leaping priests of Mars would dance in the streets.

holidays.name: Ludi Piscatorii
holidays.description: A private celebration for fisherman -- what was caught from the river on this day was burned at the temple of Vulcan, god of the forge.

holidays.name: Vestalia
holidays.description: A festival for Vesta, goddess of marriage and the hearth, honored by married women and for bakers. The keepers of the sacred flame would produce loaves from special, salted flour.

holidays.name: Matralia
holidays.description: A holiday in honor of Mater Matuta, the virgin goddess of matrons and the dawn -- offerings at her temple would bring blessings upon children and nephews or nieces.

holidays.name: Anniversary of Trasimene
holidays.description: A day considered unlucky as it was the anniversary of the defeat by Hannibal.

holidays.name: Fors Fortuna
holidays.description: A festival for good fortune -- sacrifices were made at the two shrines outside of the city, near the river.

holidays.name: Ludi Apollinares
holidays.description: Games in honor of Apollo, meant to stave off misfortune after Hannibal defeated the Romans, and again after a biological plague. The games were declared after a prophecy was found saying that they would protect the city.

holidays.name: A cursed day
holidays.description: An unlucky day, this was the anniversary of the near-extinction of the Fabius clan in 477 BC, and the defeat by the Gauls in 390 BC, which led to the sack of Rome.

holidays.name: Lucaria
holidays.description: A festival held in a grove (from the Latin word 'lucus', or 'wood'), Lucaria commemorates how the Romans were defeated by the Gauls, but then fled and hid in a wood, and ultimately defeated the Gauls as they returned.

holidays.name: Ludi Victoriae Caesarae
holidays.description: A holiday celebrating January's namesake, Janus, the god of doorways. Doorways and thresholds were considered places of vulnerability, and possibility. On the this holiday, the Romans would sacrifice a lamb for protection of the king.

holidays.name: Neptunalia
holidays.description: A celebration for the barge and dock workers of the Tiber river, Neptunalia was celebrated by building huts from boughs and leaves along the riverside and eating and drinking inside of them. It was also a day on which citizens would vote on criminal and civil issues.

holidays.name: Furrinalia
holidays.description: Furrina was a very ancient goddess of water. She had a sacred grove and a priestess, and the celebrations in her honor may have been intended to stave off summer drought.

holidays.name: Portunalia
holidays.description: A festival in honor of Portus, originally the god of keys, doors and livestock. Since his name sounds like the words for 'harbor' and 'gate', he became the god of those as well. Keys would be solemnly thrown into a fire for good luck.

holidays.name: Vinalia Rustica
holidays.description: The second Vinalia of the year, this one is a holiday for gardeners. On this day, kitchen and market gardens were dedicated to Venus.

holidays.name: Consualia
holidays.description: A day dedicated to Consus, the protector of the harvest. Much like the cellars used to store grain, his temple was located underground. On this day the laboring donkeys and mules were not permitted to work, and were wreathed in flowers.

holidays.name: Vulcanalia
holidays.description: This day was meant to honor Vulcan, the god of life-giving fire. To ward against the fires that consume harvests, celebrants would light bonfires and cast small fish into them as substitutes for humans, and would work by the light of candles to demonstrate how fire could be beneficial and safe.

holidays.name: Opiconsivia
holidays.description: A holiday in honor of Ops Consiva, wife of Saturn and goddess of the earth, agriculture, and wealth. The main priestess would wear a white veil, horses and mules were arrayed in flowers, and there would be chariot races.

holidays.name: Volturnalia
holidays.description: Volturnalia is a day in honor of Volturnus, god of the Tiber river, and was celebrated with feasts and games.

holidays.name: Ludi Romani
holidays.description: The Ludi Romani festivals were originally held if a general, desperate for victory, promised the gods that he would hold festivitiies in exchange for victory. They included a parade, chariot races, and theatrical performances -- and proved so popular that they eventually became a yearly event!

holidays.name: Ludi Augustales
holidays.description: The Ludi Augustales were games in honor of Augustus. These eventually became a ten day event under Tiberius, with the last day devoted to chariot racing.

holidays.name: Anniversary of Arausio
holidays.description: October 6, the Anniversary of Arausia, was an unlucky day associated with the anniversary of defeat at the hands of the German tribes.

holidays.name: Meditrinalia
holidays.description: Meditrinalia is a a day in honor of Meditrina, the goddess of healing and medicine. This would be the first day when Romans would taste the new year's vintage.

holidays.name: Fontinalia
holidays.description: Fontinalia is a day in honor of Fontus, the god of springs, wells, and fountains. The fountains of the city would be festooned with garlands.

holidays.name: Equus October
holidays.description: Equus October and the next holiday (Armilustrium) were both held in honor of Mars, and the close of the campaigning season. This festival was celebrated with two-horse chariot races. The right-hand horse would be sacrified to Mars. The tail would be hung in the regia over the hearth, and the head would be fought over in a contest between the rich and the poor neighborhoods.

holidays.name: Armilustrium
holidays.description: Armilustrium marked the end of the campaigning season. The soldiers' weapons would be purified and stored on the Aventine hill, trumpets would be played, and the army would be arrayed in flowers and surveyed.

holidays.name: Ludi Victoriae Sullae
holidays.description: Festivities to honor Sulla's victory, the Ludi Victoriae Sullae set the precedent of having games in honor of human achievements -- and not just in honor of gods. Only the last day was for chariot racing.

holidays.name: Ludi Victoriae Sullae
holidays.description: Festivities to honor Sulla's victory, the Ludi Victoriae Sullae set the precedent of having games in honor of human achievements -- and not just in honor of gods. Only the last day was for chariot racing.

holidays.name: Ludi Plebeian
holidays.description: The Ludi Plebeian were a great festival for the common people -- only the last three days (the 14th to the 17th) are for chariot racing.

holidays.name: Agonalia
holidays.description: Agonalia is another day in honor of Janus, the god of doors and thresholds. This day frames the end of the old year and the beginning of the new, matching the next Agonalia on January 9th. A ram was sacrified for the protection of the king.

holidays.name: Consualia
holidays.description: A holiday for Consus, god of time, Consualia marked the beginning of the end of the year. Mules and horses were draped in flowers, underground stores of grain were blessed, and the Halcyon Days -- seven days leading up to the winter solstice, and seven days following it, began.

holidays.name: Saturnalia
holidays.description: The greatest Roman holiday, the days of Saturnalia honored the winter solstice. Dice would determine who was 'King' of Saturnalia -- this person could command anyone to perform absurd tasks to entertain the others. Halls were decorated with green boughs and laurels, and light up to dispel the darkness.
